tool.name: SAGA.grid_tools.23
tool.command: $__tool_directory__/Code/openapi.py isArraySHAPESLIST True isArrayGRIDLIST True output_data_GRID $output_data_GRID name SAGA.grid_tools.23 INIT $INIT CELLSIZE $CELLSIZE M_EXTENT $M_EXTENT ADJUST $ADJUST XMIN $XMIN XMAX $XMAX NX $NX YMIN $YMIN YMAX $YMAX NY $NY SHAPESLIST $SHAPESLIST GRIDLIST $GRIDLIST USEOFF $USEOFF XOFFSET $XOFFSET YOFFSET $YOFFSET prefer $prefer response $response outputType_GRID $OutputSection_GRID.outputType_GRID transmissionMode_GRID $OutputSection_GRID.transmissionMode_GRID

param.name: INIT
param.label: Initialization Value
param.help: Value which is assigned to the dummy grid.

param.name: M_EXTENT
param.label: Extent Definition
param.option: lower left and upper right coordinates
lower left coordinate and number of rows and columns

param.name: SHAPESLIST
param.label: Shapes Layers
param.help: Shapes Layers The following data types are allowed in the txt file: json, vnd.google-earth.kml+xml, xml

param.name: GRIDLIST
param.label: Grids
param.help: Grids The following data types are allowed in the txt file: png, tiff, x-ogc-envi, x-ogc-aaigrid

param.name: XOFFSET
param.label: X Offset
param.help: Positive values result in a shift in E direction.

param.name: YOFFSET
param.label: Y Offset
param.help: Positive values result in a shift in N direction.

param.name: response
param.label: Response Type
param.help: Choose 'raw' for raw data or 'document' for document data.

section.name: OutputSection_GRID
section.title: Select the appropriate transmission mode for the output format and the output value

tool.help: This tool creates a new user specified Grid System for use with other tools.<br/><br/>First of all, please consider the following issues before using the tool:<br/>(a) all calculations of the tool refer to the lower left corner of the grid system, i.e. the xMin and yMin values. This coordinate is fixed unless you specify an offset.<br/>(b) the tool follows the philosophy of SAGA in that the values describing the extent refer to the cell centers. If you like to match the extent with the border of a grid, use an offset.<br/><br/>The tool provides four possibilities to set/determine the extent of the grid system:<br/>(1) by specifying the coordinate of the lower left cell (xMin, yMin) and the number of cells in W-E (NX) and S-N (NY) direction<br/>(2) by specifying the coordinates the of lower left (xMin, yMin) and the upper right (xMax, yMax) cell<br/>(3) by the extent of the shape(s) provided in the Data Objects section<br/>(4) by the extent of the grid(s) provided in the Data Objects section<br/><br/>After selecting the appropriate method to determine the extent, the next step is to specify the Cellsize of the new grid system.<br/>For all methods supplied to determine the extent but number (1), three possibilities are provided to adjust Cellsize and grid system extent (please remember, the lower left corner is fixed!):<br/>(I) adjust the extent to match the Cellsize<br/>(II) adjust the Cellsize to match the extent in E-W direction<br/>(III) adjust the Cellsize to match the extent in S-N direction<br/><br/>Finally it is possible to apply an offset to the lower left corner of the grid system. In this case check the Use Offset option and specify the offset in W-E and S-N direction. Positive values result in a shift in E/N, negative in W/S direction.<br/>In order to create the grid system the tool needs to create a dummy grid.
